title: Why the stock market shrugged off weak data, recession fears
summary:
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York, Aug. 7, 2025.
Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell in New York, Aug. 7, 2025.
Weak jobs data came out hours before President Donald Trump fired the head of labor statistics.
The stock market, however, hardly blinked.
The resilient stock market has generated a momentum of its own, some analysts added.

title: It’s Beginning to Smell a Lot Like Stagflation
summary:
So is inflation happening?
It’s true that many of Trump’s tariffs are clearly illegal, and the courts could force him to reverse them.
The reason many economists believe that Trump’s tariffs will raise unemployment isn’t so much their level as the uncertainty they create.
You might argue that tariff uncertainty will abate now that Trump has made “deals” with some of our major trading partners.
So tariff uncertainty remains high.

title: Average rate on a 30-year mortgage drops to lowest level since April
summary:
The long-term rate fell to 6.63% from 6.72% last week, mortgage buyer Freddie Mac said Thursday.
Even so, mortgage rates are not far from their high this year of 7.04%, which was set in mid-January.
Last Wednesday, the central bank’s policymaking committee voted to hold its main interest rate steady.
“While both buyers and sellers welcome lower mortgage rates, it’s not clear whether rates will continue to fall,” said Lisa Sturtevant, chief economist at Bright MLS.
“A weaker economy could lead to lower mortgage rates, but the risks of higher inflation could keep rates elevated.”

title: ‘Something weird’s going on’ in the economy as 6 new economic classes take shape, says New York Times bestselling author
summary:
He divides American households into six wealth levels, ranging from under $10,000 (Level 1) to $10 million-plus (Level 5 and beyond).
He’s chief operating officer at Ritholtz Wealth Management, but he’s also a blogger, and now a two-time author thanks to his latest book, “ The Wealth Ladder ,” which quickly shot to New York Times bestseller status .
“Something weird’s going on,” he told Fortune in an interview.
Maggiulli told Fortune about the long-anticipated “Great Wealth Transfer,” when baby boomers pass on their $124 trillion fortunes to the Gen Xers and millennials now in or entering midlife.
“I think a lot of people get there, and they say, ‘Wait, do I want to keep going down this path?

title: How AI Conquered the US Economy: A Visual FAQ
summary:
Nobody can say for sure whether the AI boom is evidence of the next Industrial Revolution or the next big bubble.
We can all stop talking about “what will happen if AI dominates the economy at such-and-such future date?” No, the AI economy is here and now.
Today, in a bit of a throwback to my early blogging years, I’m going to try to walk through an FAQ with graphs to create a visual guide to the question:How big is the AI boom?
“AI companies are reaching revenue milestones faster than previous generations of startups,” the company announced in a recent report.
But independent evaluators in the study actually concluded that using AI did the opposite: it increased task completion time by about 20 percent.

title: Truth Social’s new AI search engine basically just pushes Fox News
summary:
Donald Trump’s Truth Social has launched a new AI search feature that consistently pushes conservative media sources.
The feature, Truth Search AI, is powered by the AI startup Perlexity and is now available on the web version of Trump’s social media platform, with public testing coming to the iOS and Android apps “in the near future.”In our testing, all of the source links that Truth Search AI cited were for conservative publications, including Fox News, Fox Business, The Washington Times, and The Federalist.
The vast majority of these links directed users to articles published by Fox outlets, which suggests the Perplexity-powered search engine is limiting results to Trump-supporting media.
“Current evidence indicates that Trump’s tariffs have not improved the overall U.S. economy and are associated with a net negative effect, though some specific sectors benefit,” Truth Search AI wrote in response.
The sourcing pool for Truth Social’s AI search tool seems, unsuprisingly, very narrow.

title: Inside the automated warehouse where robots are packing your groceries
summary:
For an industrial space, this is eerily quiet, but it makes sense in a building where robots might outnumber people.
I’m at a warehouse — or customer fulfilment center (CFC) — operated by online grocery company Ocado in Luton, just outside London.
Image: Ocado A small suction cup is all it needs to pick up over a third of the groceries Ocado delivers.
Dubbed On-Grid Robotic Pick (OGRP), each arm is fitted with a small suction cup on one end.
Wine bottles and watermelons are too heavy for the current suction cup to handle, and a gripper might cause damage.

title: Major US alcohol groups are begging Trump to slash tariffs before the holidays to keep them from losing $2 billion in sales
summary:
Alcohol groups in the US are urging Trump toAlcohol groups in the US are urging Trump to Thomson ReutersAlcohol groups in the US are urging Trump to Thomson ReutersAs the holiday season looms, US liquor groups are begging Trump to kill the tariffs they say could ruin their most lucrative stretch of the year.
A group of 57 associations and guilds called the Toasts not Tariffs Coalition, said in a Wednesday letter to the White House that tariffs could result in a $2 billion sales loss in the holidays.
In March, Trump also threatened to impose a 200% tariff on wine and other alcohol from the EU.
Groups in the Toasts not Tariffs coalition represent US liquor heavyweights like Beam Suntory, the parent of Jim Beam, and Jack Daniel's owner Brown-Forman.
It sent a similar letter in January, urging Trump to exclude wine and spirits from his coming tariffs and convince the US's trading partners not to apply retaliatory tariffs on their products.

title: 'Shark Tank' Star Kevin O'Leary on AI Boom, Dotcom Bubble, Tariffs
summary:
"Shark Tank" investor Kevin O'Leary told BI the AI boom wasn't a bubble because you "can see the productivity and measure it on a dollar-by-dollar basis."
"Shark Tank" investor Kevin O'Leary told BI the AI boom wasn't a bubble because you "can see the productivity and measure it on a dollar-by-dollar basis."
Andrew Harnik/Getty Images"Shark Tank" investor Kevin O'Leary told BI the AI boom wasn't a bubble because you "can see the productivity and measure it on a dollar-by-dollar basis."
Impact LinkThe AI boom isn't going to collapse like the dot-com bubble, investor Kevin O'Leary told Business Insider.
The bounceback reflects greater "clarity" over tariffs, O'Leary said, adding some were "very manageable" at 10% to 15% for trade partners such as the EU.

title: Warren Buffett's Wealth Down $28B Since Announcing Retirement
summary:
Warren Buffett, the CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, has seen his wealth fall since announcing his departure.
Warren Buffett, the CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, has seen his wealth fall since announcing his departure.
Daniel Zuchnik/WireImage/Getty ImagesWarren Buffett, the CEO of Berkshire Hathaway, has seen his wealth fall since announcing his departure.
Daniel Zuchnik/WireImage/Getty Imageslighning bolt icon An icon in the shape of a lightning bolt.
Buffett made his annual donation of about $6 billion of Berkshire stock to the Gates Foundation and four family foundations in late June.
